title: Victorian Liberals prepare last-minute bid to bail out John Pesutto with loan to help pay $2.3m defamation costs
snippets:
Exclusive: Liberal sources say proposal to help former opposition leader avoid bankruptcy is being finalised

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Victorian Liberal party officials are preparing a last minute proposal for the state division to loan former leader John Pesutto enough money to pay the $2.3m in legal costs he owes to Moira Deeming.

The proposal, according to multiple Liberal sources, will need to be presented to the party’s 19-member administrative wing in order to be approved. But so far, no meeting has been called to discuss the loan and its terms, which have not been finalised.

The loan may be partly funded by the Cormack Foundation, the state party’s multimillion-dollar investment vehicle, which has so far been reluctant to support Pesutto as it is not allowed to provide financial assistance to individuals.

Continue reading...
titles: Victorian Liberals prepare last-minute bid to bail out John Pesutto with loan to help pay $2.3m defamation costs
summary: Victorian Liberal party officials are developing a proposal to loan former leader John Pesutto the $2.3 million needed to cover legal costs owed to Moira Deeming. This plan, still requiring approval from the party's 19-member administrative wing, has yet to be finalized or discussed in a meeting. The loan might be partially funded by the Cormack Foundation, although it typically does not provide financial aid to individuals. The situation remains unresolved as the party deliberates on the proposal's terms and approval.
constructiveness_reason: The story provides basic awareness about the financial situation of a political figure and the party's internal deliberation on providing a loan. However, it lacks depth or insight into the broader implications of this situation, the defamation case that led to these costs, or how this might impact the party or its policies.

title: UK politics live: minister defends Labour’s justice record after warnings of threat to public safety
snippets:
Housing minister says previous government left prison system in state of ‘criminal neglect’ amid warnings over early release plan

Shadow work and pensions secretary Helen Whately has accused the government of doing “a terrible job on keeping the country safe.”

She told listeners of Times Radio “We’ve already seen that they accidentally released a load of prisoners that they shouldn’t have done, including violent domestic abuses, which are clearly terrifying for the victims of that abuse. And they just don’t have the prison situation under control. They need to take responsibility. They’re now in government.”

What we were handed by the previous government in terms of the state of our prison system was nothing short of criminal neglect. They added just 500 places to the prison estate in their time in office, while at the same time, sentence lengths rose, and as a result, we got the prison population rising by approximately 3,000 people each year.

And we’re heading back to zero capacity. If we run out of capacity, courts will be forced to suspend trials, the police will have to halt arrests, crimes will go unpunished.

Continue reading...

Housing minister says previous government left prison system in state of ‘criminal neglect’ amid warnings over early release plan

Housing minister Matthew Pennycook has defended the government’s record on prisons and sentencing in England and Wales after criticism from senior security officials, but said “we can’t build our way out of” prison capacity pressures in the short term.

Earlier today the Times newspaper reported that the heads of the Metropolitan police, MI5 and the National Crime Agency have told the government that plans to release prisoners early could be of “net detriment to public safety.”

What we were handed by the previous government in terms of the state of our prison system was nothing short of criminal neglect. They added just 500 places to the prison estate in their time in office, while at the same time, sentence lengths rose, and as a result, we got the prison population rising by approximately 3,000 people each year.

And we’re heading back to zero capacity. If we run out of capacity, courts will be forced to suspend trials, the police will have to halt arrests, crimes will go unpunished.

Housing minister Matthew Pennycook has defended the government’s record on prisons and sentencing in England and Wales after police chiefs warned that sentencing reforms could put pressure on frontline services

The government has announced a package of measures it says is designed to streamline the planning system for small and medium sized housebuilders

The Treasury is reported to be in a standoff with some ministers over proposed cuts to public services including policing and social housing

Nigel Farage has been accused of leaving a multibillion-pound black hole at the heart of Reform UK’s spending plans after unveiling a series of expensive policy pledges to be paid for by cutting nonexistent items of government spending

The national water regulator Ofwat has fined Thames Water nearly £123m after two investigations into the company

London mayor Sadiq Khan has called for partial decriminalisation of cannabis possession

Continue reading...
titles: UK politics live: minister defends Labour’s justice record after warnings of threat to public safety
UK politics live: minister defends Labour’s justice record after warnings of threat to public safety
summary: The UK Housing Minister, Matthew Pennycook, defended the government's handling of the prison system amid criticism over its state and early release plans, attributing issues to the previous administration's "criminal neglect". The prison system faces capacity pressures due to a minimal increase in places and rising sentence lengths, leading to a potential halt in trials and arrests if capacity is reached. Senior security officials, including the heads of the Metropolitan Police, MI5, and the National Crime Agency, have expressed concerns that early release could harm public safety. Additionall
constructiveness_reason: The story offers useful context on the state of the UK's prison system, the government's handling of it, and the potential implications for public safety. However, it does not report on any solutions, improvements, or attempts to solve the problems identified.

title: Albanese says ‘we follow our own path’ after UK, France and Canada threaten Israel with sanctions over Gaza
snippets:
Labor MP Ed Husic and former Labor foreign ministers Gareth Evans and Bob Carr reiterate support for targeted sanctions

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Anthony Albanese has appeared to downplay the prospect of Australia imposing sanctions on Israel over its actions in blockading aid into Gaza, saying his government would “follow our own path” despite allies like the United Kingdom threatening further actions against Benjamin Netanyahu’s administration.

The prime minister shrugged off calls by a pro-Palestine group within Labor for targeted sanctions on Israel, saying he was focusing on “peace and security for both Israelis and Palestinians” rather than “soundbites”. But Labor MP and former cabinet minister Ed Husic again said his government should consider sanctions against those directing operations against Gaza, while former Labor foreign ministers Gareth Evans and Bob Carr also endorsed sanctions.

Sign up for Guardian Australia’s breaking news email

Continue reading...

Labor MP Ed Husic reiterates support for targeted sanctions to oppose Israel’s actions in Gaza. Follow today’s news live

  • Jacinta Nampijinpa Price demoted from shadow cabinet, Jane Hume dumped as Coalition unveils new frontbench

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Nationals frontbencher Bridget McKenzie has insisted her party never made free votes for cabinet members a condition of returning to Coalition with the Liberals, as the two parties draw closer to a deal.

McKenzie also took a shot at Liberal MPs who were giving her and her colleagues free advice. She told Channel Seven’s Sunrise:

There are many Liberal MPs who want to give us gratuitous advice about how to run our party room. I’m happy to give them membership forms if they’d like to join it. But a coalition works best when everybody respects the independence of both parties.

That wasn’t put to the room.

Continue reading...

This stance comes despite pressure from within his Labor Party, including calls from Labor MP Ed Husic and former foreign ministers Gareth Evans and Bob Carr, for targeted sanctions against those responsible for operations against Gaza. Albanese's approach diverges from actions considered by allies like the United Kingdom against Benjamin Netanyahu's administrati

title: Zelenskyy to meet Merz amid German wrangling over weapons go-ahead – Ukraine-Russia war live
snippets:
Chancellor’s coalition partners opposing any moves to allow Ukraine to use long-range Taurus missiles

  • Zelenskyy bound for Berlin with Merz boxed in

Hours after Zelenskyy spoke, Ukraine unleashed one of its largest ever drone barrages on Russia, firing almost 300 drones at the country, according to the defence ministry in Moscow.

Russian officials reported only minimal damage from the attacks.

Trump confirmed that if Russia does not stop, sanctions will be imposed. We discussed two main aspects with him – energy and the banking system. Will the US be able to impose sanctions on these two sectors? I would very much like that.

Russia will announce the next round of direct talks between Russia and Ukraine soon Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov said on Wednesday.

The neutral status of Ukraine remains one of Russia’s key demands in the peace negotiations, Lavrov added, according to Reuters.

Trump confirmed that if Russia does not stop, sanctions will be imposed. We discussed two main aspects with him – energy and the banking system. Will the US be able to impose sanctions on these two sectors? I would very much like that.

title: Future of Maradona trial in doubt as scandal-hit judge steps down
snippets:
Julieta Makintach accused of behaving ‘like an actress’ after shooting documentary about trial of footballer’s medical team

A key judge in the trial of the late Argentinian footballer Diego Maradona’s medical team has stepped down amid a scandal that has cast doubt on the future of the high-profile case.

Julieta Makintach, who has been called the “judge of God”, recused herself after it emerged she had been shooting a racy miniseries about the months-old trial, potentially breaking a string of ethics rules.

Continue reading...

title: The imperious finals record held by Spanish teams
snippets: Spanish teams have been invincible in finals.  Since 2002, Spanish teams - including the national team - have played in 27 finals across the World Cup, European Championship, Champions League and Europa League/Uefa Cup and all 27 have had Spanish winners.  Four Spanish club sides have been defeated in that time, but in all cases by fellow La Liga sides.
titles: The imperious finals record held by Spanish teams
summary: Since 2002, Spanish football teams, including the national team and club sides, have maintained a perfect record in 27 major finals across the World Cup, European Championship, Champions League, and Europa League/Uefa Cup, always emerging as winners. While four Spanish club teams have lost in these finals, their defeats were exclusively to other teams from Spain's La Liga, ensuring that the trophy always stayed with a Spanish team.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides basic awareness about the success of Spanish football teams in major finals, but it lacks depth or insight into how these teams achieved such a record, the systems or strategies they used, or the impact of this success on Spanish football or sports culture.

title: The world could experience a year above 2°C of warming by 2029

title: World Record Broken: New Material Revolutionizes Ion Conductivity

Now, researchers at the Technical University of Munich (TUM) and TUMint.Energy Research [...]
titles: World Record Broken: New Material Revolutionizes Ion Conductivity
summary: Researchers at the Technical University of Munich (TUM) have created a new material that significantly improves ion conductivity in solid-state batteries, setting a world record. This development is a major step forward for solid-state batteries, which are more powerful and safer than current lithium-ion batteries as they do not contain flammable materials. title: Bed bugs are most likely the first human pest, new research shows
snippets: Ever since a few enterprising bed bugs hopped off a bat and attached themselves to a Neanderthal walking out of a cave 60,000 years ago, bed bugs have enjoyed a thriving relationship with their human hosts.
titles: Bed bugs are most likely the first human pest, new research shows
summary: Bed bugs have been living with humans for approximately 60,000 years, originating when they transitioned from bats to Neanderthals. This long-standing relationship began when early humans presumably came into contact with these insects in caves, leading to bed bugs adapting to human hosts and thriving alongside them throughout history.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides basic awareness about the history of bed bugs and their relationship with humans. However, it does not offer actionable insights, solutions or a deeper understanding of the issue. It doesn't discuss how this knowledge could be used to address current bed bug infestations.

title: AI-powered weather forecasts could miss extreme storms
snippets: Weather forecasts based on AI are faster and sometimes more accurate than traditional ones, but they may miss rare and unprecedented weather events – which are becoming more common as the climate changes
titles: AI-powered weather forecasts could miss extreme storms
